p: After rigorus researches on animal models, it has now been proved that B. ciliata, B. ligulata, and B. himalaica possess an antidiabetic property [ 71]. The EtOH extracts of B. ligulata roots exhibit a remarkable hypoglycaemic effect in diabetic rats [ 108]. Saijyo et al., (2008) isolated the antidiabetic principle ( Î±-glucosidase inhibitor) from B. ligulata rhizome extract by column chromatography, which was characterized as (+)-afzelechin ( 6), by NMR technique [ 61]. The antidiabetic property of B. ligulata can be useful in developing nutraceuticals (value-added food products) for diabetics [ 61, 71, 108].
